div1.head: Report fragment on malaria in England, in 1917 and 1918, by [Henry Rose Carter?], [19--]
div1.p:
Reports and Papers on Malaria
Contracted in England in 1917 and 1918.

Issued by
the Local Government Board

These papers give the “reaction” of England to the importation
of a large number of men infected with malaria in 1916: /17 and /18
so far as had been determined to June /19--the date of the last paper.
They are of interest to us in America, especially to those in regions in
which malaria was, but is no longer, prevalent. The reports on the
current year and the two or three following ones will be more so.

In the past malaria was prevalent in many parts of England so
as to be of “serious sanitary importance.” Shakespeare is full of
allusions to agues: James 1 and Charles 11 both.suffered from it and
Cromwell died of a tertian fever. The Lincolnshire fens and parts
of Kent especially enjoyed (?) a bad reputation and I presume a cer-
tain immunity among the natives as a Fen man is exhorted not to
take a wife “out-foreign” as she “was sure to die of ague:” the
speaker, a Fen man (and a fictitious character) having had this ill
luck three times. In some sections--as in Kent, south of the lower
Thames--it was prevalent up to 1869 and /70 and maybe longer.- in one to 1911
England was generally believed to be free from it at the time
of the beginning of the war.

Nuttall and Strangeways Pigg--1903 to 1904--found Anopheles
of three species quite commonly distributed in the low lying parts
of England, one species of which--A. maculipennis--the old world ana-
logue of our quadrimaculatus--is known to be elsewhere an efficient
vector of malaria. Unfortunately, attention was concentrated rather
on the fact of finding Anopheles than on the number found--i. e.
2
whether they were numerous enough to be “of sanitary importance,”: so
the surprise of these gentlemen at the absence of malaria in Eng-
land, in spite of its frequent introduction from abroad, is, I think,
not justified by their findings as published. (Foot note)
_________________________________________________________
(Foot note) The survey implies, however, a considerable--or even
large amount-of breeding at some places. (End of foot note)
_________________________________________________________
The unknown “third factor” (in addition to Anopheles and infected
men) predicated as necessary for the conveyance of malaria and absent in England may have
been in many cases a temperature for much of the time so low that
the full developement of the parasite in the mosquito took place
either not at all or so slowly as to materially reduce the efficiency
of the insect as a vector. Anopheles, of course, may be active at a
temperature well below the optimum of that for the developement of
the parasite in them.
The factors necessary for the conveyance of malaria are obviously:
(1) Men infective to Anopheles mosquitoes:
(2) Active Anopheles of sufficient numbers to serve as vectors:

(3) Temperature suitable for the full developement of the para-
site in the mosquito, and
(4) Men accessible to the infective mosquitoes.

In 1916:/17 & /18 a large number of men suffering from malaria
were brought to England from the Balkans: Gallipoli and, I presume,
from Palestine and Egypt. How many one can only guess. In the re-
port made in March /18 by Ross 2,460 cases are reported in 1917 as
undergoing in hospital specially devised therapy to prevent relapses.
The total number under treatment should be several times more than this.
Angus McDonald reported 2,417 “proven carriers” (by blood examination?)
3
at three places only at which malaria had been contracted in 1917.
He says the “actual number was obviously much greater.” A conser-
vative estimate would be that from 10,000 to 20,000 men infected with
malaria were introduced into England in 1916 and 1917--a less num-
ber in 1918--probably 15,000 to 20,000 in all. And they were pretty
well scattered in England too, in Camps: villages and small towns.

Very obviously there was abundant material to infect Anophe-
les if other conditions were suitable and they were so infected.
During 1917 there are reported to have been contracted in England
231 Cases of Malaria:163 in the Army:25 Navy:43 Civilian
" 1918/95 " " "61 " " "9 "25 "
In all:--326 " " "224 " " "34 "68 "

Twenty-nine foci of infection were established: All cases were
tertian--the “benign tertian” of British writers,-although from 26% to
32% of the infections at the places of origen were Aestivo-Autumnal--
“malignant tertian.” We may note here (1) that this form seems to be
less apt to relapse and (2) certainly requires a higher temperature
for sporogony than the simple tertian. 270 of the cases occurred
in Kent: 234 in three districts: Sheppey (an island south of the
mouth of the Thames): the Isle of Grain and Sandwich.

At first the infection was, naturally, ascribed entirely to
that derived from the imported infection, but a closer examination
showed itsits existence, and in some amount, in Queensborough (in the
Sheppey District) and in Isle of Grain prior to the advent of the
soldiers. (Foot note)
_____________________________________________________________
(Foot note) It existed also in the Romney Marsh area as late
as 1911. (End of Foot note)
_____________________________________________________________
This is not asserted of Sandwich, although in the same general sec-
4
tion. The later conclusion was then that a certain number of these
cases are true indigenous infections: the remainder being contract-
ed, through English Anopheles, from the soldiers infected overseas.

S. P. James is very positive in claiming a marked clinical
difference between the indigenous infections and the imported ones.
The first being far milder and little subject to symptomatic re-
lapses the second being extremely severe and relapses frequent. No
difference in the morphology of the parasites was made out. The
Sandwich cases were in general mild, as much so as those from Queens-
borough. By this test a number of them would then count as indi-
genous infections. It seems then that malaria was not entirely ab-
sent from England at any time, but lingered in very mild form in a
few places and was discovered owing to the careful investigation
caused by the cases of malaria contracted in England showing among
the troops and among civilians in contact with troops.

The report shows that no measures likely to be sufficient to
prevent the spread of malaria were taken in 1917. In 1918 measures
of control were much better applied. In the Sheppey district: Sand-
wich and Romney Marsh, where the great bulk of the cases occurred,
measures for the control of mosquito production were undertaken.
Generally, however, they were the prompt report of cases and their
sterilization by quinine--Colonel James formulating the treatment.

To my mind the point in this paper which stands out as of
prime importance is that, with the importation of not less than
15,000 men infected with malaria during three years, the total num-
ber of cases reported as contracted in England in two years was only
326326----some of which were contracted from pre-existing (indigenous)
infection. Very obviously malaria shows little tendency to spread
5
in England.

This will be better seen if we look at the statistics for
1917 by themselves, as the measures for control of that year may--
I think--be almost disregarded. From 10,000 to 15,000 infected men
imported and only 231 cases contracted in England (43 among civilians)
If these conditions of conveyance continue, the malaria introduced
in 1917 will be “of no sanitary importance” within a year or two.

I think we may take it as a rule that if the biological condi-
tions of the insect host are such that malaria once prevalent spon-
taneously disappears - or undergoes great diminution -, the introduction of carriers--no matter in
what number--while they may cause an outbreak of malaria, yet this
will be temporary only and malaria will spontaneously decrease and
disappear or undergo the same diminution if these conditions of the insect host remain the same. XQueens

(Foot note) The same will hold if the malaria has been reduced in the
community by a change of biologic conditions of its Anopheles to a cer-
tain stationary amount. It will, after the flare up from the introduc-
tion of carriers, spontaneously return to the same degree of infection.
(End of foot note)
what the number of infections we start with, we would have a de-
creasing series, which would ultimately reach a number “of no sanitary
importance.”

It would be inaccurate to say that the rate of decrease in
England is 15,000 to 326 per annum. On the one hand, a number of re-
lapses will occur in 1919 and /20 among the cases alreadypreviously imported,
which will infect others in addition to the 326, and, on the other,
when the soldiers are demobilized they will live less commonly in
camps in the country, where Anopheles most abound, and even there their
house contact with other people would be less intimate than in barracks
